title: Littondale Walking Route

nearby.description: Kettlewell to Starbotton and Arncliffe Walk

images.title: Brian C Payne / Stone Bridge near Litton
images.caption: Stone Bridge near Litton. The bridge leads to an Other Route with Public Access over Cow Close Fell.

images.title: Tim Cook / Icy pools in the River Skirfare on a bright November day
images.caption: Icy pools in the River Skirfare on a bright November day. Taken looking towards Litton from the Bridge near Spittle Croft

images.title: John Illingworth / CC BY-SA (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0)
images.caption: Houses near the river at Litton

images.title: Malcolm Morris / Bridge over the River Skirfare.
images.caption: Bridge over the River Skirfare. Taken near Litton in the Yorkshire Dales. This river like others has gone underground for its high summer exposing the limestone pavement.

images.title: John Illingworth / Heber Side Barns
images.caption: Heber Side Barns. A series of field barns at the head of Littondale, near Nether Hesleden

images.title: Paul Glover / Halton Gill from the slopes of Plover Hill
images.caption: Halton Gill from the slopes of Plover Hill. The small hamlet of Halton Gill nestles towards the head of Littondale.

images.title: Alexander P Kapp / Halton Gill to Litton road
images.caption: Halton Gill to Litton road. This quiet country lane runs between the two settlements and is good for walking on.

images.title: Paul Glover / The Old Church
images.caption: The Old Church in the picturesque little hamlet of Halton Gill

description: This circular walk explores lovely Littondale in the Yorkshire Dales. The route runs for just under 5 miles with some small climbs on the way. There's lovely river paths and fine views to the surrounding hills to enjoy. The walk starts in the little village of Litton, located on the River Skirfare. From here you can pick up footpath heading north west to Nether Hesleden. You continue following the course of the river to Halton Gill. This little hamlet is situated at the northern end of Littondale. The route then turns around and follows a country lane back to Litton, with more nice river views on the way.
